text: For a few weeks in 1996-97, it seemed that Daniel Hooper was the most famous man in England. Swampy, as he was known, spent seven days in tunnels excavated under the path of the enlarging A30 near Exeter. The A30 protest ultimately failed, but its like has been replicated several times since then and “Swampy” has become a catch-all for any environmental activist taking to the earth or the trees. It is a term that is being heard once again.

Having finally gained the backing of the prime minister just before the pandemic began, construction work started this month on Europe’s largest infrastructure project. The first phase of the HS2 rail line snaking through the Chilterns and Shakespeare country is due to deliver high-speed train
image: Protesters clash with security officials at the HS2 site in Denham, Buckinghamshire

text: Extinction Rebellion’s insurgent tactics have brought cities to a standstill. Until recently, however, little consideration had been given to what happens when the climate activists “go floppy”.

This limpness has now come into the spotlight, as Scotland Yard’s deputy commissioner branded them a “flipping nuisance”. The problem, according to Sir Stephen House, is that protesters become a “complete pain in the neck” when they deliberately go limp when being detained, requiring several officers to carry them away. He called on them to behave like adults.

Sir Stephen told the London assembly’s police and crime committee yesterday: “We have asked them to stop being floppy. It might seem like a silly thing to say, but when we arrest them and pick them up they go all
image: Police arrested 680 people in connection with Extinction Rebellion protests in London earlier this month

text: A woman with nine children appeared in court yesterday with 50 others accused of being involved in an Extinction Rebellion blockade of printing presses.

Natalie Bracht, 45, appeared at Luton magistrates’ court via video link from Stevenage police station on one charge of obstruction of the highway. The court was told that she had been offered legal representation but turned it down.

She is among 51 people who have been charged with obstruction of the highway after the protest in Hertfordshire on Friday night. Extinction Rebellion targeted the Newsprinters print works, which produces newspapers including The Times, The Sun, The Daily Telegraph and the Daily Mail.
Ms Bracht initially failed to respond to questions about her name and personal details and did
image: Natalie Bracht lives in a squat near Heathrow and turned down legal representation when she appeared before magistrates yesterday

text: David Cameron has revealed he was left red-faced by the diaries of a Tory MP’s wife that detail his personal feuds, drinking and sex jokes, admitting: “It’s kind of embarrassing.”

The former prime minister insisted that he could not recall an incident described by Sasha Swire, wife of the MP Sir Hugo Swire, in which he allegedly joked that her perfume made him want to push her “into the bushes and give you one”.

But in an interview with Times Radio to be broadcast today — in which he also called for Jeremy Hunt to return to frontline politics — he had his head in his hands as he said that the betrayal by longstanding friends was not what you wanted “splashed all over the
image: David Cameron said Sasha Swire’s memoir was not the sort of thing you wanted “splashed all over the place”

text: The veteran eco-warrior known as Swampy was the last person forcibly removed from an anti-HS2 treetop protest camp by police as they tried to protect an ancient woodland which inspired Roald Dahl to write Fantastic Mr Fox.

Four specially trained climbing officers from Thames Valley Police scaled the 60ft canopy protest camp by hanging from two cranes on ropes. They faced four hours of resistance before all ten protesters were arrested and brought down to waiting police vans.

Swampy, 47, whose real name is Daniel Hooper, was the last of the protesters perched in the treehouse in Jones’s Hill Wood near Great Missenden, Buckinghamshire, where the children’s author Dahl lived.
Hooper and his son Rory, 16, joined the group, who have been occupying the
image: Activists had occupied Jones’s Hill Wood for months
Daniel Hooper, known as Swampy, was the last of the activists evicted from ancient woodland in Buckinghamshire

text: Flight from the city isn’t just about the wide-eyed pursuit of birdsong and breathable air. The urban escapees setting their sights on Stroud are every bit as focused on the traditional fundamentals of good schools and transport links as they are on its unrivalled sense of community and the lush Cotswold countryside all around.

There are certainly plenty of them. Gemma Goulding, manager of the local branch of Hamptons International estate agency, saw an 80 per cent increase in would-be buyers over the summer compared with last year. Although more than half are from London, plenty are coming from Bristol too. “So many people just don’t seem to want to live in a city any more,” she says.
Not that they’ll be cutting themselves off.
image: Fennells Home Farm near Stroud is on the market for £1.35 million with Strutt & Parker

text: In the spring of 2018, I was viewing the Picasso exhibition at the Tate Modern in London with Mark Carney, then governor of the Bank of England. We were in a group guided by a curator who stopped at an endless number of paintings to ask, “Can you see here the imagery representing Picasso’s penis?” To focus our attention, he gestured up and down with his hand. On the fifth or sixth occasion, the curator stopped by a big painting of a reclining woman in purples and pinks and asked again if we could see “the penis extending here, from the face and head”. At that moment I caught the governor’s eye and I corpsed. “Are you absolutely sure,” Carney deadpanned when we were released

Across Laurence Fox’s open-plan sitting room, I glimpse the future. It’s possibly, although one hopes not, the future of British politics. Almost unavoidably, it is the future of Laurence, the well-loved scion of the Fox acting dynasty who has recast himself as the leader of the anti-woke brigade’s brand new party.
At first I think the huge bloke I spot in his kitchen must be our photographer, so I call out that I am wrapping up the interview. He looks puzzled. That’s no snapper. That’s Fox’s bodyguard.
“Paul keeps an eye on me,” Fox explains. “He makes sure no one throws a punch.”
Is he is joking?
“No, there are some nasty people out there.”
And the party pays for Paul?
“The party has a
image: Laurence Fox, 42, at home in south London

text: Publish a political diary about the Tories in power and sit back and watch an entire colony of nose-diving gannets try to skewer a single shrimp astray from its shoal.

Gosh, the stuff that was written about me! Apparently I am, among other things of course, a frustrated housewife, a flesh-eating sexaholic (which came as news to my husband, I can tell you), a Lady Macbeth, a Becky Sharp figure, a member of the Devil’s Generation (Thatcher), a failed It girl and cabinet wannabe, an anti-Semite, a traitor, a vulgarian.

The headlines that festooned the Mail’s pages were particularly colourful and flapping in the winds of publication. I was even dispatched by its favourite columnist, Sarah not so Di Vine (as my husband calls
image: Some of the coverage when the book was released
Sasha Swire, 57, at her home in Devon

text: Two of the HS2 protesters holed up in tunnels dug in secret near Euston station are children of the millionaire owner of a remote British island.

Blue and Lazer Sandford, 18 and 20, are committed Extinction Rebellion campaigners who live part-time on Gometra, in the Inner Hebrides. The island has no cars, mains electricity or internet in homes.

Roc Sandford, their father, is a landowner and publisher who often joins them at protests. A climate activist himself, he recently gave his children Christmas presents made out of rubbish he found on Gometra that he reclaimed into art and wrapped in old newspaper.
The siblings, real names Isla and Lachlan, are among a group of campaigners called HS2 Rebellion who have spent months digging a
image: Lachlan “Lazer” Sandford with his father, Roc Sandford, who is also an environmental campaigner
Roc Sandford with Blue, in glasses, and another of his daughters

text: An island laird has said that he fears for the lives of his son and daughter who are burrowed deep in a protest camp tunnel 500 miles away.
Speaking from his home on the Hebridean island of Gometra, Roc Sandford, an environmental activist, criticised health and safety chiefs.

Sandford said he had lodged a complaint with the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) for failing to halt eviction tactics he claims have put the lives at risk of his daughter Blue, son Lazer, and other protesters.
Blue, 18, and Lazer, 20, are in a 100ft-long tunnel secretly constructed under Euston Square Gardens in London by activists protesting against HS2’s high-speed rail development plan.
As safety fears grow for the small band of eco warriors who
image: Roc Sandford said he was proud of Blue, right, and Lazer, with sister Savannah

text: It was one of the defining pictures of the Extinction Rebellion protests in October 2019: Lord Fraser of Corriegarth, a Tory donor and former party treasurer, emerging from his home in the heart of Westminster clad in nothing more than a white dressing gown and monogrammed slippers to confront a colourful band of noisy protesters whose carnival had turned from Smith Square into Lord North Street.

Jack Hill, the Times photographer who caught the occasion, recalled: “It is a beautiful street and I ran ahead to capture the contradiction of the protest band and the genteel surroundings. I noticed a man at his front door in his dressing gown and slippers. He saw the band and started waving his fist angrily at them. Was he
image: Fraser would have kept his low profile were it not for the Lord North Street set-to

text: To lose one child in an underground network could be regarded as misfortune — to lose two looks a little careless. Yet Roc Sandford, 62, does not appear surprised. The father of 18-year-old Blue, who is occupying 100ft of tunnels beneath Euston Square Gardens in central London in protest against HS2 after her brother Lazer, 20, left the site last night and was arrested by police, smiles mysteriously when asked at what point he discovered his children’s plans: “I’d rather not say.”

Before Lazer’s exit the siblings had been down there for two weeks already, as the HS2 contractors attempted to evict them without risking lives. Sandford has been in contact with his children. They have been able to text him because there is mobile
image: Lazer, left, lying down, and Blue, with glasses, have gone from remote Scottish island to dank tunnels under London. Savannah, in the orange jacket, is also a green campaigner

text: Anna Hursey was ten years old when she made her international debut on the professional table tennis circuit. A year later the Welsh prodigy became the youngest athlete to compete in the Commonwealth Games.
Alongside her fierce competitive streak, which has seen off adult opponents, runs a passion to tackle the climate change crisis, which caught her attention when she began watching the news.
And now, still aged only 14, she has been spotted by President Biden, who has asked for her help in making his climate initiative a success.
The US embassy sent her a message last week inquiring if she would help the president to tackle what it said was the “most urgent priority” of his administration. Anna was asked to speak
image: Anna Hursey, who is ranked No 1 in Wales for under-15s, says she is “a bit nervous” after the US embassy asked her to help President Biden’s climate change initiative

text: A total of 20 police officers were injured and some feared they would be killed in Bristol last night in a riot that police are describing as the worst case of violent disorder in the city for a decade.
One officer suffered a punctured lung and another a fractured arm as a protest against a proposed law to enhance police powers degenerated into violence in the early evening.
Two police vehicles were set on fire while officers were attacked with fireworks and pelted with bottles in a four-hour stand-off.
Police and witnesses to the violence said that the clashes arose after a peaceful protest involving more than 3,000 people had come to an end.
Andy Roebuck, chairman of the Avon and Somerset Police Federation, said
image: Crowds gathered to oppose anti-protest legislation

text: A rare insect thought to be extinct in Britain has been found alive and well and living in the Outer Hebrides.

The caddisfly Limnephilus pati, once a native of the East Anglian fens, was unrecorded in the UK for more than a century until a male of the species was attracted to a light trap, owned by Robin Sutton, an amateur entomologist on the island of South Uist.

Sutton, who has attracted 23 species of caddisfly to his light trap over the years, said: “I’ve been running a light trap for over four years but I couldn’t believe that the only location for a species thought to be extinct in Britain was in my back garden.
“It goes to show how much we still
image: Limnephilus pati was unrecorded in the UK for more than a century

text: Judges used to be household names. Lord Denning, never publicity shy, once appeared on Wogan alongside the singer Ian Dury, and the chat show regular Judge James Pickles had his own column in The Sun.
The law is more self-effacing these days, but Jonathan Sumption has become something of a celebrity, partly because of his outspoken opposition to lockdown.

The retired Supreme Court judge is a former Oxford history don, the author of a series of books about the Hundred Years’ War. He is a linguist who speaks fluent French and Italian and reads Spanish, Portuguese, Catalan, Dutch and Latin. He is a music lover who sits on the board of English National Opera. As a polymath, he is Jonathan Miller in a horsehair
image: Holding court: Sumption calls lockdown ‘government folly’

text: Saturday morning in Stroud is always a spectacle, and last weekend was no exception. Families queued at stalls selling doughnuts, the smell of Thai food filled the air and a lone woman strode past carrying a large piece of cardboard bearing the words “stop racism”. In every direction beautiful wooded hills appeared through gaps between buildings, while on the restored canal, a dog in a life jacket floated past on a paddleboard.

“There are all sorts of things going on here, but everyone has the aim of keeping Stroud independent and local,” says Dominic Salter. A Stroudie for 30 years, he is typical of this former industrial town where adaptability, innovation and local pride are the norm. Salter is one of the bosses of the
image: Best Places to Live in the UK: Stroud is spoilt for choice with excellent schools, transport links and countryside

text: Joss Garman was one of the first to be arrested. Before dawn on a Monday in October 2007, the 22-year-old and 50 other environmental campaigners invaded Kingsnorth power station in Kent. Eon, which owned and operated the station, had applied for planning permission to build a coal-burning facility on the site — the first of a wave of new power stations planned for the country.

The strategy for the protest was simple: flood the site with so many activists that the security team could not halt them all, and shut down the station. “We stayed in a farmhouse in bunks the night before, got up at 3am and all got into minibuses,” Garman, now 35, recalls. “We climbed the fence and went through these dusty
image: From left: Alok Sharma; Isabella Tree; Sir David Attenborough; Rosamund Adoo-Kissi-Debrah; Chris Packham

text: Joe Biden has landed in the UK for the G7 summit in Cornwall, his first overseas visit since becoming US president in January.
The president and his wife, Jill, touched down in Air Force One at RAF Mildenhall in Suffolk this evening.
He was expected to address a crowd of US air force personnel there before flying on to Cornwall for the summit, which begins in Carbis Bay on Friday.

Hundreds of British troops, including bomb disposal teams and a navy warship, are joining more than 5,000 police officers and a 400-strong US Secret Service team at the summit this weekend in one of the biggest security operations undertaken in Britain.
The armed forces are being drafted in to help police as world leaders, their
image: The president and first lady arrived in Britain on Air Force One this evening

text: Pace of change and knowledge development are so rapid within the natural world that nature writings can quickly go out of date. There are also rebel species that loathe being imprisoned within empirical boxes, none more so than our haughty purple emperor butterfly.

So, having published what some (but not me) may regard as a definitive treatise on this recalcitrant insect, I find a significant revision is due — not because I got something badly wrong (that nightmare may yet arise) — but because a breakthrough has occurred in an area formerly closed to study. A set of traffic lights stuck interminably at red has suddenly turned green.
The insect spends three weeks in the pupal period, suspended from a leaf in the upper regions
image: It has been recently discovered that purple emperor pupae glow prominently in the dark under the beam of a powerful UV torch

text: David Attenborough could not have arranged it better. A chorus of birdsong bursts down the Zoom call. The beaming, Harry-Potterish face of Hugo Ticciati, one of classical music’s most endearing eccentrics, looms into view. “Look at this,” he says, and swivels his computer so I get a panorama of trees, endless trees, massed in what seems like an impenetrable forest.

“Is that where you live?” I ask, looking out at my own domestic vista: the backyards of Kilburn, north London. “Yes,” Ticciati replies. “In the middle of the Swedish forest. By myself. For 21 years. Basically, I met the Russian violinist Nina Balabina in London when I was 19, and she gave me such an inspirational violin lesson that I thought, ‘I have to go
image: Hugo Ticciati has lived in a Swedish forest for the past 21 years

text: You have to feel a little sorry for Keir Starmer. The more he attempts to come across as a normal human being, the more he sounds like a speak-your-weight machine that has suddenly been afflicted with self-righteousness. The more he attempts to convince us that his party is eminently sensible and fit to govern, the more shrieks of manifest derangement emanate from his backbench MPs. Chic radical posturing and, to quote Lenin, infantile leftism.

There are protests and riots in Cuba because they don’t have enough to eat, can’t get medical supplies and have no freedom. Thuggery is being used against the demonstrators, as you might expect. But for a large tranche — perhaps the majority — of the Labour Party, Cuba’s only problems are
